Ok so you guys kinda got it right but......
It's not an "AIR" layer....it is a Hydrogen layer
We know that water is comprised of H2O.....2 Hydrogen atoms and one Oxygen.
The 2 Hydrogen atoms surround one oxygen.
Thus, due to 2 Hydrogen atoms surrounding one oxygen at the surface there is a very thin Hydrogen layer.
Of course this Hydrogen layer cannot be ignited or anything because of the strong molecular bonds of the valence shells.
And Hydrogen being one proton and one electron......we also know that like charges repel one another.
Therefore....on the surface....we translate surface tension as The Hydrogen layer at the surface repelling the like charged Hydrogen layer of the water droplets.
Until......the droplet can arrange itself to then molecularly bond by arranging the hydrogen atoms with the other oxygen atoms of the underlying water that it is resting upon...and finally blend in...this takes a moment of time.
We can observe this Phenomenon even more ......by witnessing flakes of Gold floating upon the surface of water.
Q. ---How can this be possible when Gold's SG is 19 times that of water being much heavier.....but the Gold floats.
Same reason.......the Hydrogen Layer at the surface of the water (One electron) Is Repelling the one Electron in the Valence shell of the gold until the surface is disturbed enough for the water to Coalesce and finally bond to the surface of the gold flake...and then the gold will sink.
With water droplets of course it disperses into more water volume.

One time when I was trying to germinate Sea Rocket seeds I noticed that the seeds had a strong attraction to any solid objects including the sides of the glass. After much research I learned that this is likely an example of the Cheerios effect albeit a strong Cheerios effect stronger than other objects including Cheerios that I compared them to. I haven’t been able to look at the Sea Rocket seeds under a microscope but I think the structure of the surface of the seeds plays a role in its strong Cheerios effect. This makes sense because Sea Rockets uses water to distribute its seeds and the seeds need to find solid ground in order to mature into a plant. Anyone interested the Cheerios effect or biomimicry should check this out. This video reminded me of that experience being a surface tension related phenomenon.

Almost. The next is not told because it was not needed in this about surface tension.
If a droplet nears a water surface, the distance between the water surface and the bouncing molecules of the droplet is still great because of the air between them (Oxygen and Nitrogen molecules). One molecule between them is enough to keep the distance to big. It takes some time to get rid of all the air between them and get the right distance between the compressed molecules to overcome the existing Hydrogen bound in the surfaces. Because of the compression the Hydrogen bound is stronger at the surface than inside the water. So the droplets and surface must come real close to join droplet and water.
The speaker let the droplets dance over the surface. There is not enough time to let the surfaces come so close to overcome the compressed molecules attraction because the air is coming between them when jumping. The rest is told above.

I hope the problem is solved by this explanation.

It has nothing to do with air, but resonance. The vibration of one water source, adhering as a unit by surface tension, interacting with another water source (or any soluble liquid - perhaps any water-soluble substance) of a different resonance must reach an equilibrium of action in order to coalesce. It's about vibrational entropy and energy equilibrium. The higher energy source shares it's energy with a lesser energy source until the two are approximately equal in energy output, and then the two may act as a single unit (coalesce). Note: It was stated that it would be thought that the air would be pushed out of the way rather rapidly and wouldn't be expected to bounce so much before coalescence, however, when the droplet bounces, it creates a gap between itself and the water surface. This creates a pressure difference that would pull air back into the pocket, causing the droplet to have to push it away with LESS force on each successive bounce, as more air than was pushed out of the way would be drawn in, reducing the energy of the droplet further before hitting the body of water again.
Eventually, this entropy would result in a form of harmonic resonance whereby the two bodies can synchronize and coalesce.

This phenomenon is caused because of surface tension of the water, and all substances have different surface tensions. A solid has more surface tension then a liquid. I propose the reason the drop persists is an electromagnetic effect because Oxygen exists unbound in the atmosphere as a diaelectric molecule. A Beckman Model D2 oxygen analyzer used this fact to move a mirror with a magnet and "display" the oxygen concentration in a sample of gas. The more oxygen in the sample the more the magnet would move the mirror and light would reflect off the mirror on a scale in the view port of the analyzer.
As the drop of H2O falls through the "air" (21% O2) the surface charge of the drop increases in the presence of the higher O2 in the air. The lowering of the ambient pressure would indeed lower the magnetic charge due to the decreased concentration of the available oxygen molecules. As soon as the surface charge between the water pool and the drop reach equilibrium the drop coalesces in the pool. In the sound wave experiment the drop is "rubbed" on the air cushion and the surface charge persists a bit longer not unlike a comb and the static charge when rubbed on a wool sweater.

I've enjoyed 'floating water' since as a child I swam in a large pond in the rain, and saw that most of the raindrops are nearly the same size and the same as the droplet that pops off the top of each rebound water spike, and jump back up to a uniform height (about 2") and each jump releases a fan of smaller droplets that skitter about, interfering/riding on the nearby wave formations. It was an enthralling light show of dancing droplets. I always suspected that the electrical properties of surface tension contributed to the 'lubrication' that inhibited the skitterers from melding immediately.
. Re 9:20 The cello is mellow, ie mostly first few sine wave harmonics. These compression waves are able to form strong (focused) nodes on the negatively curved (inside) surface, strong enough to eject droplets, which then drift off with little enough speed to be unable to rejoin the sphere easily. Wish I had more physical statistics in math class, and a better understanding of how Van der Waal's force affects the surface tension.
. As for the theory that it is the viscosity of air that provides the lubrication, I still think that is not enough, though I do enjoy dropping a large pane of glass onto a flat surface & relying on the viscosity of air to prevent it shattering. Fun stuff!!!

You notice Don started with a sine wave, then showed a square wave and a triangle wave.
9:20 "There's something about the cello..." the cello (and other string instruments) produce a sawtooth wave, which ramps up linearly, then has an abrupt decrease in amplitude. My guess would be that this sudden negative delta in pressure would facilitate the smaller droplets shearing off from the internal air/water boundary. And apparently they occur more readily at a frequency resonant with either the diameter of the internal air sphere, the diameter of the water sphere, or the thickness of the water sphere. So a sawtooth wave, swept through that frequency range should work, much like the cello music.

Hey, Destin. I don't think the phenomenon has anything to do with a "cushion" of air under the water droplet as much as the air pressure around the water droplet is causing the surface tension to be amplified. I know surface tension is molecular attraction. What I'm suggesting is that normaly the pressure from inside the water droplet is getting counteracted by air pressure allowing the surface tention to do its thing. When air pressure drops, internal thermal pressure can break surface tension and the water boils.  So there doesn't have to be a cushion. Maybe try the experiment in much higher air pressure and see if you can get a stable anti bubble!

9:20 "There's something about the cello..." the cello (and other string instruments) produce a sawtooth wave, which ramps up linearly, then has an abrupt decrease in amplitude. And apparently they occur more readily at a frequency resonant with either the diameter of the internal air sphere, the diameter of the water sphere, or the thickness of the water sphere. Want to learn about something just as cool? Take a gander into the firefighting world and how we have evolved from smooth bore nozzles which create almost a laminar flow to the use of fog/combination nozzles that create little droplets of water. Before we had to directly attack the seat of the fire to extinguish it. Now we are taught to open the door to the room that's on fire, spray a small burst of water in any direction and close the door. Those water droplets quickly turn to steam and that steams cools and extinguishes the fire or knocks it down pretty hard. The other cool thing with fog nozzles is when we turn the nozzle head to the left, it creates this big wide cone that shield us from heat and flames, all because of those little water droplets that effectively insulate from the heat. Also, a final note to intrigue you. If we spin that nozzle tip about a quarter to a third to the left from far right, it creates what we call a power cone and using the venturi effect, will clear out a room full of smoke in seconds. Something you should look into. It's right up your alley.

In my opinion, It's not the air under the droplet that enables it to float and scoot around and seemingly defy gravity.
It is each molecule's substantial electrical and magnetic fields and alignment of polarity in relation to each other and to the sphere of the droplet, which substantially help keep the droplet together, so that it can defy its own weight and tendency to sink in and mix with the larger area or body of water. It's like two magnets with the same polarity next to each other, that vigorously repel, but also eventually try to flip and switch alignment of poles to attraction. So all around inside of the droplet, the molecule's magnetic polarity do two things, one, they keep the droplet tightly together, and two, all around the surface of the sphere of the droplet, the molecule's magnetic charges repel, and support the weight of the droplet, until some of the magnetic charges realign, possibly and eventually by getting influenced by randomly spinning polarity in the molecules in the larger body of water, until some of the magnetic fields switch to attraction, and then the droplet gets absorbed into the larger body of water. That is my opinion on it, It's probably even more complicated and interesting than that on an atomic level. Later in this video with the blob of water in outer space, you can see the effects of the water's self attraction, and it's resistance to breaking apart unless affected by just the right frequency to have a vibration compromise the magnetic fields for a brief moment and let a certain amount of water molecules to break away from the larger body. The outside surfaces of each body of water have similarly charged polarity so as to repel each other's surfaces and not allow absorbtion, while they bounce around. I think that's pretty close to what's going on, but I'm not a super highly educated scientist. Just an amateur scientist...

Destin, I think you have lead me to understand a phenomenon I read about decades ago.  Back in the 1970s, I read in one of the Foxfire books that moonshiners would gauge the completion of the distillation process by watching for a "bead" dropped from the condenser into the collection vessel to form on the liquid surface.  Alcohol has lower surface tension than water, so its drops don't hold together strongly, and I am thinking they are not strong enough to withstand collision with a liquid surface, so they spread out and coalesce more rapidly than water and probably faster than the eye can discern.  When distillation of a mash is complete, its temperature rises and water starts to boil off and be condensed.  The higher surface tension water droplets obviously can withstand impact with the liquid surface, and thus a bead with long enough "hang time" to be observed after dropping from the condenser.  I wish I had your slow-motion camera so I could try dropping alcohol in alcohol and water in alcohol to see if this theory pans out.
Surface tension is the tendency of liquid surfaces to shrink into the minimum surface area possible. Surface tension allows insects, usually denser than water, to float and slide on a water surface.

The air is not the major factor for this resistance between the drops and the water mass , but mainly the equal negative electric force which exist on the surface of a water mass and repel each from other.

One layer deeper into the physics, the surface tension is caused by the alignment of water molecules at the surface. When the surface of the droplet approaches the water surface below those aligned molecules at each surface are the same charge and repel each other. In order for the water to coalesce, the water molecules in each surface have to rotate so they do not repel. They have to break the attraction to the molecules right behind them in order to rotate. All of this takes time and this time should correlate to the amount of time the droplet spends on the surface.

In addition the sound waves in the water cause the droplets to bounce back up giving the molecules in each surface time to realign for maximum surface tension and the process has to start over. The shape of the waves also reduce the freedom of movement of the molecules at the surface so it is harder for them to realign.

There should also be certain size droplets that always form, becase certain sizes will have the most stable arrangement of molecules that are most difficult to disrupt. I think there is more going on here than described.

What if...
The water falling from the source has enough kinetic energy when it first hits a target (like the surface of a pond, cup of water, bath, urinal) to splash a small amount of water back up in the air (this is the normal reaction) which then forms a small sphere due to surface tension, but does not have enough kinetic energy on the second “bounce” to break that surface tension and coalesce back into the greater body of water (which also has opposing surface tension). Then, because of the surface tensions in the droplet and main body of water, the droplet has enough residual energy to slide across the surface until reduction in that energy allows the two object’s surface tensions to be disrupted by some imperfection in one of their surfaces (dust, hair, mineral) to allow the tensions to be broken, ultimately allowing the droplet to be reabsorbed into the greater body of water?

Less than a minute in, but going to take a shot with a hypothesis. Probably a mixture of surface tension, temperature difference, and impurities.

The droplets are really small, so surface tension could be helping to hold its shape. There is also likely air being trapped between the surfaces, preventing contact temporarily. Impurities on the surface might also help with this prevention.

I think temperature difference might also be involved due to how when 2 bodies of water of differing temperature meet, they tend not to mix easily. I believe there was a good example of this with where 2 large rivers join, one clear, and one muddy, and they stay fairly clearly divided. I think this was in a rainforest. I can't remember.
Answer? Gravity variations.

Destin - but you've not described in detail the surface tension of the water and the differing temperatures of the base (larger) body of water and the smaller droplets.  Different temperatures between droplet and main body effectively results in 2 different density bodies approaching each other.  Therefore the molecules are misaligned and so they do not mix.  The temperature difference is balanced out very quickly on impact and the main body transfers its temperature (heating or cooling) to the water droplet.  Once temperatures are equal, molecules align and the droplet is 'absorbed' into the main body.  I think that this is a more accurate description of what is happening rather than the 'air gap' theory.  I do not have any scientific backing for this - just 25 years of being a military engineer.  Great, mind-expanding videos, keep them coming and lets get this information out to the young budding engineers out there.  Thanks.

Hey, I don’t know if anyone else has commented, but I have two ideas why the cello specifically created that phenomenon. The first is that it’s simply the range of the cello (a low to midrange, C2-A5). That frequency range may resonate well with that size of bubble, regardless of what instrument plays the note.

The second is that it’s the timbre of the cello that causes the smaller bubbles to form inside the air bubble. The cello sounds unique because of the way that all of the specific elements (strings, bow type/style, kind of wood, etc) combine to amplify certain overtones which create the distinct sound. These amplified harmonics might cause the perfect surface conditions to create the bubbles. It’s along the lines of when Don cycled through the different wave types while experimenting with frequencies in space.

My theory:
Water molecules create a different structure or position when exposed to air, which is different to that of when they are close to each other, this is commonly known as surface tension, which is clearly visible when water striding insects are able to exploit it. With both separate bodies of water having their own surface tension in place this doubles the tension effect. As water has memory (see works of Victor Shauberger and experiments by Masaru Emoto as a reference), when the air between both bodies has gone the water does not immediately react, as it's air to water structure is memorised for an instant. However, when vibration is added this memory is extended, due to the feedback, thus the two tensions repel for longer.

I have an idea about why the cello produces drops. In the video of the drop coalescing (3:52) as the main drop coalesces it almost leaves behind a mini drop about a quarter of its size (something about the ripple traveling around the surface of the drop) then as the mini drop coalesces it almost leaves behind a micro drop about a quarter of its size. It's my understanding It's all about surface tension. H2O molecules are in the form of a triangle. There is a very strong bond between the hydrogen and oxygen pair. Surface tension is due to these triangular molecules aligning in one direction at the surface due to their charges. Like charges repel, opposites attract. The molecules align in such a way that not only do the water molecules on the surface plane attract one another, but that outwardly they repel along the plane. A water droplet is a group of molecules that because of this same principle, project this repelling force outwardly as sphere. Water does mix with water but when water molecules are all aligned the surface and the drop both have the same charge. It's not a large charge, but it is there nonetheless. As the drop settles and the air molecules are pushed out, eventually this is overcome by proximity of the molecules, not unlike the flipping of a magnet in proximity to another magnet with the same pole. Once those molecules on the surface begin spinning around, there is a cascade and the the drop merges. Under the right conditions and with pure enough water, one might be able to suspend a drop indefinitely.

I would think if you could zoom in enough with the high speed camera, you might be able to detect the deformation of the water surface as the drop approaches, before it actually makes contract. This would definitely illustrate the like charges repelling.

You might also try to see if smaller drops last longer.

I believe the smaller the drops, the stronger the surface tension is. Surface tension is much like a "skin", similar to the latex of a water balloon. Larger balloons are weaker, smaller balloons are stronger. Water drops are the same as the molecules that makes/ produces the surface tension are "stretched" thinner/ weaker in a larger drop (or flat surface) and are thicker/ stronger in smaller ones. And it is the dissimilar skin strengths that helps to prevent the coalescing much the same way temperature differences prevent mixing of liquids and vapors. Vibrations will "shake" at different frequencies as well causing the dissimilar skin strengths to be even further apart, a shearing effect if you will, allowing the drops to remain whole longer before coalescing. Electric instruments like electric violin or guitar or the synthesizer is going to produce a consistent wave. A cello or violin is going to produce a wave that's scattered, imperfect and inconsistent.

4:04 - My first guess will be this is due balance of forces; the air gap works to first reduce points of contacts between the bead and the main liquid surface, and just works to prevent the bead from joining the rest of the liquid at the onset of the first few bounces. This can be tested by dropping the droplets from different heights at different liquid levels on different types of hard surfaces. As the height increases you will expect more bounces, same with shallow liquid level, same with liquid on hard surface (try this on an angled smooth granite surface with shallow liquid flowing down). For the liquid molecules on the surface of contact line there is a net force keeping each in their camp, as the air gap diminishes the difference in these net forces also start to diminish and the molecules in the boundary between the 2 surfaces now begin to accelerate their mixing, this will happen so fast as to create a somewhat shock-wave which is seen in the video. All other properties of the liquids (temperature, viscosity etc) will also play an effect depending on how they play into these force differences.

Resonances happen with sound waves as well as light waves and even gravitational waves. What I’ve discovered along the way is that when any two waves interact, if the frequency of the waves are just right, they become almost “symbiotic.” Meaning, they don’t necessarily increase in amplitude or frequency, but they create a repeating pattern that’s that’s more than just a single peak and valley long. It’s greater than the sum of the two waves, so to speak. There seems to be something special about, what musicians call, “the perfect fifth.” What this means is that when a note or chord with two waves per unit of time is played at the same time as a note or a chord with 3 waves in the same unit of time, the waves interact in a unique way which to the ear sounds much richer. This also repeats all the way up the piano in a predictable pattern so it doesn’t matter if the two notes are high or low ones. All over the world we see intuitive examples of it in the Buddhist’s chanting “Ohm...” The more monks chanting, the greater the harmonic richness. It’s in the certain bells which have the exact right curvature to produce this harmony. It shows up in many things. Why? And why, when you hear it, you feel this great sense of relaxation? I believe that somehow the vastly complex interaction of the vibrating bits that make up living things, miraculously produce this perfect fifth harmony as both a fundamental union of whatever this whole crazy natural world is, but it’s also an emergent quality of the final product - life. 9:50 so the cello is a very rich sounding instrument. And this is for a reason. Because it actually covers a very large frequency even though it is technically a low frequency. I'm not convinced that an air gap explains the initial repulsion between the falling droplet and the surface of the pool. Most of the unique phenomenon observed in water are due to its polar nature. I suspect that this behavior is no exception. Mind you, this is my own hypothesis, so don't ask for references...


If you think about it, the falling droplet and the water globule in orbit are both micelles, formed in free fall, which negates tidal forces caused by the acceleration due to gravity. In the absence of gravitational influence, water molecules in the falling droplets, being polar and having an electrical dipole moment, align themselves to neighboring water molecules due to van der Waals forces, or hydrogen bonding, just like little magnets. The positively charged hydrogen ions are attracted to the negatively charged oxygen ions in neighboring molecules, creating a cohesive force that tends to keep the droplet from drifting apart. The same phenomenon causes molecules on the droplet surface to form a cohesive elastic "skin" with a net inward pull because there are no water molecules to pull the surface molecules away from the droplet. The force vector acting upon the surface is directly toward the center of the drop . We call this skin "surface tension" and it takes a surprising amount of energy to break it. We've all seen a steel sewing needle float on water in beginning physical science class.


A funny thing about surface tension is that it too is polar as the bent water molecules tend to arrange themselves with their central oxygen atoms pointing outward and the positive hydrogen atoms inward. Remember, each central oxygen atom in water has two pair of non bonding electrons just hanging out, repelling the valence electrons in the OH bonds and warping its water molecule into a 104.5 degree dogleg. Granted, the net charge of the whole droplet is zero, but the outer surface carries a strong negative charge. It's what makes lightning possible as these electrons can be stripped off through collisions with other water droplets.


The water in the pool also forms a polar surface tension with an electrical dipole moment, just like the falling droplet. Since like charges repel one another, the falling droplet is going to begin encountering upward repulsion between its negative surface charge and that of the surface tension of the water in the pool. This upward force will increase exponentially as the gap narrows until it exactly cancels the downward force of gravity, at which point the drop will hover very close to the surface of the pool, without contacting it. It's most likely a combination of induced charge migration and random molecular activity (Brownian motion) that causes the droplet to eventually contact and merge with the pool. This hypothesis could be easily tested by conducting the droplet experiments under ozone producing ultraviolet light (Hg 184.95 nm), which tends to decrease the dipole moment of water molecules exposed to it, reducing the surface tension. Just be sure to wear sunscreen and UV goggles. The use of deionized water should slow down charge migration in the water and increase the hover time of the micelles if it is electrostatic repulsion and not trapped air levitating them.

I first noticed this phenomenon in a cup of coffee in a styrofoam cup. If you slide the bottom of the cup across a smooth surface (preferably formica0, the cup will vibrate, and suddenly, little beads of coffee drink jump out of the surface of the liquid and dance around on the surface of the coffee in the cup. I was astounded by this because of the incredibly strong surface tension of water! How is it possible the vibration can be so powerful it breaks the beads out of the liquid under the surface tension force? If you stop the action of sliding the cup, stopping the vibration, the surface goes almost completely calm and flat, but the bead of water stays on top for quite a long time, several seconds. I do not understand then, how the so-called "air boundary" between the bead and the surface can be responsible.


Here is what I think is happening: I think the nature of the surface tension of water somehow traps the bead surface tension when it is formed into the small spherical shape, making it more powerfully attracted to itself than to the flat water. Just as the surface tension of flat, calm water can trap a steel razor blade on top of the surface, the trapped or "closed" surface tension of the bead gets trapped on the top of the surface tension on the main body of liquid in the cup. I think the nature of the "closed" surface tension of the bead, is actually repelled (or no longer attracted as much or enough) by the flat surface tension - the beads tend to mostly return to the main body when they get near the side of the cup- where the surface tension of the flat surface is distorted by the surface of the cup, and possibly by electrostatic influence from the styrofoam.


I think this phenomenon is attributed more to the shape of the water surfaces than to the air trapped between the two surfaces or the added energy of the vibrations that made them. The attraction between water molecules is just too strong for the trapped air to be the primary causal effect. .. although it almost certainly is a contributing factor.


It would, of course, require someone far smarter than I am to work out the physics of the difference in closed sphere water surface tension vs. flat water surface tension. There seems to also be some sort of limit to the size of the spheres involved. They seem to be quite uniform in size regardless of the other factors.

with recordings of a solo acoustic instrument, particularly if they are close mic'ed and no effects are added. Playing it back results in the speaker taking on the acoustic properties of the instrument as it was being played. The drivers on the speaker will vibrate just as the soundboard of the instrument did, be it a cello or a piano. Cellos & Violins have a very special harmonically rich buzzing tone that really speaks to the human heart (soul or whatever you want to call it) it is intoxicating like an aural drug. Great effort is made by audiophile and studio speaker manufacturers to make their speakers sound neutral / invisible enough so that a stunning likeness of instruments can be heard. Because generally the resonance of the cabinet and other materials significantly changes tone/timbre and the resonant droning notes. In these bouncing water experiments the water itself is acting as an acoustic soundboard and although we cannot hear it, the visual effect shows it. And this I find very novel and satisfying, to "see" the acoustic properties of water!

You should measure the size of each drop (using that camera?) before it hits the surface and see if there's a correlation between the drop size and it's likelihood to bounce/survive. The size of each drop would determine its internal resonant frequency and I expect that determines the likelihood of a soft bounce and therefore a longer survival (resonance) time. The needle helps to make consistent drop sizes (try a different sized needle) which helps generate the identical conditions needed to see this repeatedly. Other variable that need testing are the volume (and shape) of water below the drop which may impact the base water's internal resonant frequency. Also you made no mention of the pH or purity of the water (eg, distilled?) So many variables and none of them were tested. Even the purity of the air (and humidity) could have a huge impact on the survival rate since we are talking about microscopic distances between the drop and the water below it. In some of your clips of this phenomenon it seems that all the surviving drops have the same size (or multiples of the same size) so the internal resonant frequency idea "holds water."

Man, I have a theory that maybe something different than this "air-gap" however, please feel free to challenge my thoughts on this: this water droplet is made of the same material H2O yet it has not coalesced with the water structure that is bound together in a "pool" obviously, but I think the structure of that water vibration is basically under a pressure of sorts, and the drop-trying to be integrated, takes shape as it falls, has a motion, and the pressure constantly changing, is what keeps the droplet separate from the pool, rather than Air between the drop.  Think of it like this: you have seen the stuff called Ublek? just a mixture of cornstarch and water, right? That stuff will solidify as pressure is applied to it, becomes a solid and yet it will mesh as soon as the "stress" being applied is relaxed.  I think that is similar. I may be wrong, but maybe this will be proved . . . to be true.  If anyone wants to challenge this theory, prove I'm wrong.  I don't see air-gaps between the water(s)      Or . . . Let me put this way.  Can a liquid be pressurized to the point of suspense?  Example: as a vibration moves through the liquid it is synchronized. The droplet which has no or a different vibration cannot instantly meet the rhythm exactly.  Thus, momentarily it gets suspended in its most natural shape.  There is no gap between the two, it simply a difference in pressures.

The way instuments in the violin family (such as the chello) family ceate sound is uniquely differnt from most other typs of instruments. When instruments that are strummed or struck create sound they vibrate in a reletivly even pure fashion. However when the strings on a chello vibrate the vibrations are very sharp and iregular as the bow sliding over the strings is constantly interupting the vibration of the string as the two come in and out of contact with each other, creating soundwaves of difering legnts and amplitudes within the same note.

Ok, if I was going to speculate on this, I would say that this phenomenon is the result of vanderwall interactions between water dipoles.  The water molecules on the surface reorient to have a small charge on the surface and an internal charge to match.  When 2 surfaces come close they repel until some of the molecules reorient due to Brownian motion.  Then the dipole charge collapses and you get the drops merging.

This phenomenon is very easy to understand. The basic principle deals mostly with rotational velocity versus surface tension. Basically they are both water and thus "should" just become one again, however because of the movement of the water droplets through the air, a barrier is generated due to the difference between the molecular vibration of the gaseous air and the liquid water. There is at that point an even amount of pressure around the water droplet and now that it is isolated and falling, the movement can't spread beyond the boundaries of the water bubble in motion so that downward velocity must be diverted continuously and thus generating a rotational movement. The bigger body of water is stagnant in comparison to the rotation of the smaller water droplet and so as the droplet spins it is moving too quickly to breach the surface of the bigger body of water. after a few milliseconds or seconds the bubble has slowed down due to a two part system, friction from the body of water and the water droplet being close and putting pressure on the small gaseous barrier between them as well as energy dissipating as the droplet rotates. After the droplet has slowed down, the surface tension of the droplet lets up and gravity begins to act more on the droplet and the movement of the droplet and the surface tension of the bigger body of water are significantly closer. The droplet gets too heavy to be supported by the small gaseous barrier and so it descends, penetrating the barrier and falling into the bigger body of water. That's about it.

I was once an audio major, and though what I'm about to say isn't scientific, I think you'll be able to extrapolate my intention to one of understanding.

Concerning the cello, and why it causes the droplets to break apart and float around inside the air bubble; the cello is an instrument of sustained friction induced sound. Running the bow across the strings creates vibration through friction, sustained friction. Other instruments, like wind, most percussion, and even a piano result sound from instantaneous pressure changes due to air or instant impact. Even a drum, though sustaining a partial friction based impact initially, the sound is produced due to the change in air pressure resonating off the head and walls of the drum.

With bow and string instruments, we have an entirely different source and cause of sound. Continuous Vibrational Friction of materials is necessary to create and sustain the sound, and the moment that ceases, the sound diminishes rapidly, depending of course on the tension of the string in question. Whereas in a wind instrument, the molecules themselves are being vibrated inside the instrument to generate sound.

Given that, the medium through which the molecules are vibrating emanates from an entirely separate kind of source of sound causing inducement. As such, I would wager a guess that a) if you were to further study this at a deeper level you may reach the answer as to why they cause this and nothing else causes this effect, but more importantly b) it suggests that molecules can vibrate in entirely different ways given the method in which they are induced to do so, causing different forms of sound. Much like a square, sine, or sawtooth wave, the idea could be that the molecules vibrate in just a certain way that is different than that of non-friction inducing sources. Think nails on a chalkboard.

I hope that makes sense, and as I said, it's not scientific, just a theory.

There is actually a better explanation than an air layer but I'm sure that plays a roll. In reality water at an air-water interface undergoes a phase transition where the water molecules are oriented in liquid crystal chains due to their polar dipole moment. This (North-South-North-South) bonding structure is much stronger than the bulk water and the interaction of the two surfaces will naturally be of like charge and therefor they will repel!

Look into this liquid crystal phase of water, so much technology we're missing out on with simple water as the main ingredient.
Perhaps we will make a boat one day that uses this kind of tech to float!

I saw the first few minutes, and was like, "Oh duh, air between water surfaces. Differences in surface tension caused by temperature and concentration." Then I saw the cello clip, and was like, "yeah, that's the coolest thing I've seen in my life."

The reason why only the cello made that happen, was because with other music, there are more than one factors, like drums, bass, and vocals. With the cello clip, there wasn't any drums or people singing, which would create one tone at a time. With the other music, many different factors and tones played at the same time cause the air inside the water to vibrate, but at different frequencies depending in the factors. There were multiple things contributing to it at once. With one tone played differently, the vibration would be so concentrated that water droplets are forced to repel from the rest, creating the phenomenon. This phenomenon is just like how one pin could pop a balloon (cello) but many different pins (other music) balanced it and didn't pop.

Dustin, I have ben intrigued by vibrations all of my life and have learned that there is a frequency for every material, but the AMAZING part is the question; When does the Input vibration have an astounding effect on it's material? ANSWER; "When the input frequency "RATE OF CHANGE" corresponds to the material's frequency "RATE OF CHANGE" close enough that the Input frequency is able to "DRIVE" the Materials frequency to a state that becomes unstable"  THIS action seems to require a fluctuating input frequency such as would be produced by a stringed instrument (Cello). I like to think of it in terms of pushing down a dead tree. You usually can't just push a tree over usually you need to push then wait then when the tree swings away from you again you push again. and as you are doing this you will realize that the energy in the swinging tree grows with every push you give eventually reaching the breaking point.     EXAMPLE #2 whistle at the side of a wine glass or piece of steel that will "RING" you will find that certain tones will make the steel "RING" "POPEY THE SAILOR MAN" is a good song to whistle. I forgot what note does it but I first noticed an "I-Beam" ringing every time I hit the certain note as I was whistling. I later realized that if I whistled strongly the same note at the beam it would ring but if I whistled the note slowly dropping the tone - nothing - slowly Rising the tone I would get a stronger ring out of the beam. ..... I wish I had seen this video and the previous one much earlier because I, too, had observed the same phenomenon decades earlier and was curious about it. As a chemist, I think the phenomenon may have other causes in addition to the layer of air separating the drop from the bulk water.  I have observed that the addition of dish detergent (and other surfactants) to the water prolongs the droplet's life time, which suggests that the surface chemistry plays a role.  The organization of water molecules (or detergent molecules when present) at the liquid's surface impedes the coalescence of the drop by forming a barrier (a molecular skin, if you wish) that has to be disrupted before coalescence can take place.

MY guess about this has to do with intermolecular forces which, in an existing body of liquid (even as small as a drop) has established the electron bonds between one other. When you drop the liquid on the other body the charge bonds need to change orbital directions, that is, what I see in my mind is the vectors of the electrons must be altered to create a new bond. And, since this is pre-established in a droplet, there is some resistance to obtaining the new electron bonds. In other words, they like what they are bonding to, and are resisting altering this bond to accommodate a new relationship or cohesive attraction, Surface tension is a simple way to describe it. In my mind it has nothing to do with an air layer, but you say that lower ambient air pressures will hasten the integration of the droplet. I still think it must have to do with electron bonding, perhaps the air plays a role in it, too.

As far as "science", the lower air pressure experiment is the best experiment. But now you have another question.

Suppose you had a dirty needle and as the water dripped out, they had a thin coat of oil around them. The beading of the water would not be very surprising at all. But instead of oil you have a skin of air. Why? Why is the air bounding to the surface of the water droplet (and probably to the surface of the still water as well).

The lower air pressure indicates that the air layer that bounds with the droplet is smaller and easier to penetrate. "indicates" but doesn't "prove" it. Perhaps the lower pressure relaxes the forces caused by surface tension for some reason.

For your theory to work, there must be some type of adhesive effect going on between the air and the water causing the air to want to coat around the water droplet. The boundary stays with the water droplet as it bounces and skitters around.

The whole theory is based upon the air gap. But we never see the air gap. Seems to me the next step in validating this theory is two things. More magnification and focusing on the air gap. I'm not sure high speed frames helps. Perhaps have the lens half in and half out of the water or perhaps under the water looking up. Perhaps using fiber optics to get closer to the point of contact. It should be possible to "see" the air gap because of various things like the light diffracting through the various layers.

Obviously there are two boundaries between the two bodies of liquid but you seem rather confident that there is an intermediary air gap. To me, that still has not been shown. And, if / when it is shown, then the question is: why does the air bind so tightly to the water?

I would also question the purity of the water and utensils being used. Is there a thin "skin" of impurities instead of air?

They are giving to much credit to air pressure...
The problem is the "drop" is retaining it's own gravitational field and the molecules inside the drop are arranged to accept the pull of the drop more so than the water beneath it.
The air between them lessens the pull of the water but is not necessary to achieve the experiment.
The best way to explain this is through the dropping of the drop by the syringe.
Notice the water clings to itself until it is at a critical state. Then it drops.
Notice also that the critical point happens when the sphere starts changing by X much.


I argue that the drops cling to itself until it's shape changes X to much from the original sphere. When this happens it becomes apart of the larger object. Because the molecules of the drop are now more arranged to accept the larger object, and less arranged to retain the sphere.
(spheres are the best object to retain pressure)

When the water is bouncing due to frequency it is not allowing the air barrier to increase, infact if you go to any "sub woofer" and feel the air, it creates low pressure in the speaker... What the frequency is allowing the drop to do is retain it's shape. By juggling the sides of the water drop and retaining the sphere. When the drop hits the peak of a wave it breaks because the sphere is changed by X much.

Furthermore, if it was air, the more velocity the drop had the more air resistance (more trampoline effect) the drop would experience and bounce off or split into many smaller drops... Also the sphere deforming would create a bigger surface area creating more repulsion.

however, if my theory is correct velocity would deform the drop breaking the tension and the drop would mold into the bigger object nearly instantly.

What about a cello: All bowed, string instruments, ie violin, viola, cello, double bass, produce a saw-tooth waveform (at the string) this is a saw-tooth with a sloping leading edge and a fast release trailing edge. Most other tonal instruments produce sinusoidal waves.  Even though the body of the instrument will alter the saw-tooth wave to some degree adding harmonics, and the sound transmitted through the air to the recording microphone further alters and filters the waveform, it still remains a saw-tooth wave. This is analogous to an earth quake where kinetic energy is built up slowly over time and then suddenly released in an instant - either earth plates suddenly moving to new positions or the string of a cello snapping back to it's starting position. As a reproduced sound, I speculate that the sudden release of energy in each wave is high enough (especially in the lower frequencies) to break the surface tension of the wave peaks produced on the surface of the water. Because of the lack of gravity the energy that breaks the surface tension is also enough to send the drops bouncing around inside the bubble.

I have another theory that explains the phenomenon and submit the government report, unless much more comprehensive, fails to address the issue.

How do we know there is an air cushion between the two at all. The elasticity of the droplet is due to the strength of its surface tension. The surface tension is a factor of the intermolecular bonds throughout the droplet.

So when kinetic impact/rebound energy is introduced to the droplet, how do we know that kinetic energy is simply too weak of an internal force to break the intermolecular bonds of the droplet?

By lowering the air pressure, of course the internally induced (impact/rebound) kinetic energy could more easily "burst through" the droplet's surface tension and cause coalescence. The molecules throughout the drop have lost the 14 pounds per square inch of external, atmospheric pressure that was constantly surrounding the droplet. External pressure was being applied uniformly to its entire surface - now the pressure is gone - hence it would take less internal/rebound kinetic energy from within to overcome the strength of the intermolecular force's ability to adhere to one another.
.

Another thing to consider is the water droplet should have a greater elasticity to begin with than than the water surface it impacts. I see this as being akin to a rubber ball impacting a large rubber block sitting on a table. Vibration will be "felt" throughout the entire block, but its mass won't let it move as much as the smaller ball will move. However, the result of impact for the ball's much smaller mass is translated into upward motion against gravity.

Both the rubber ball and rubber block have the same surface tension coefficient if they are the same rubber. The surface tension coefficient is powerful enough so the rubber ball does not splat on impact Until an external force great enough would break its ability to retain shape).

Unlike rubber though, water is a liquid. Thus the droplet can coalesce, whereas the rubber ball will simply rebound. However, the physical laws are the same until they come up against the affects that will occur due to different states of matter.

So what migh be happening at the point where the doplet coalesces?

When the kinetic energy from multiple impacts is finally gone, the droplet rests upon the water surface. For the first time the droplet's mass is not only putting a CONSTANT pressure on one small area of the surface, but now that same pressure induces the molecules on both surfaces to interact while in constant contact (I realize we are talking minute intervals of time - but we are also using minute particles of mass). I have to wonder if there is not even a more enhanced affect from the water's surface "side" of the interaction due to it greater mass?

Destin, thanks for making this. My observation of this phenomenon predates yours. I first noticed it in the 1970s when I was doing lots of oil painting. I noticed that when I cleaned my brushes in turpentine I could easily create the little raised bubbles/balls by flicking the brush gently on the surface. They skitted around the surface of the jar of turps. I thought it was a surface tension effect caused by the mixing of different oils with the solvent and I also thought the bubbles/balls were spinning. I did notice that as they slowed in their horizontal movement they were more likely to coalesce with the turps. All this is consistent with your explanation involving air pressure. Later, I noticed the same phenomenon in hot drinks and on the surface of water. I still wonder if the balls were actually spinning - this might just have been an illusion - and it will be hard to tell if they are. The micro gravity experiment you showed was instructive as it demonstrates the role of surface tension in the creation of the balls and the reason why they are only ever very small (it's surface tension vs gravity). So thanks again for making the video and offering a clear explanation.

Electrostatic repulsion and surface tension. Both the body of water in question and the water droplet are subject to electrolytic charge and surface tension.  The droplets you are observing occur when the water droplet has a opposite electrolytic charge than the body of water it is falling into, since the charge is present in the surface of the droplet and the body, the surface tension of both the droplet and the body of water repel each other until the charges equalize.

I would think that this has more to do with the force of surface tension keeping the bodies separate.

A pocket is made in the water that the drop lands on do the the surface tension of the drop deforming the surface of the water. This would be due to the surface of the drop, as well as the water, having their water molecules aligned so that the poles are opposite of each other, thus repelling. With water having a positive pole at the hydrogen end and a negative pole at the oxygen end. For this example the surface of each body would be positive or negative. In the "Theory vs Experiment: What is the Surface Charge of Water," it was found that equilibrated water (water exposed to air) has a negative charge. The surfaces would repel each other and there would in fact be an air gap.

Once the bodies are in proximity for enough period for the poles near the surface of each body to align they merge. This would also explain why when the droplet merges with the water it does so violently and, as seen in the video @3:46-3:56, the upper portion of the merging droplet begins to form another droplet body. With the poles continuing to align and merge the body faster, smaller droplet bodies continue to be made until the entirety of the droplet mass merges with the larger one.

I wouldn't doubt that the droplet bouncing is effected by air between the bodies, though I do not believe that fully explains what is being observed.

Cool video, but you didn't take in consideration of a key fundamental property of water that holds water together at the molecular level. The edge of water is made up differently then the center of the same water mass at the molecular level. This is what kept the water in place at zero gravity and allows drops of water to bounce on a larger mass of water here on Earth. It's also is responsible for allowing certian insects and lizzards to walk and run on water. You can fill a glass of water past the top of the glass and the water hangs on slightly until pressure from gravity finially breaks the molecular water bonds and it spills over the edge. It would be interesting using your high-speed camera to film the same experiment in a vacuum sealed chamber with no oxygen in the chamber. Very interesting topic. Thanks for sharing.

What I do think causes this is just the surface stress of the droplet. Under normal conditions, every liquid is a non-Newtonium fluid; the effects are just too small to actually observe. What happens here is; the droplet just meets the optimal size of "self"-cohesion, meaning the forces within the droplet are strong enough to counter-force the cohesion on bigger scale, when combined with high stress of the impact area. In other words, the droplet cohedes with itself and the uneven distribution of stress helps the progress.

Water beads floating on water is explained by hydrogen bonds. The negative side of water has the oxygen atom, which is attracted and wants to bond with the positive charge of the hydrogen of a nearby water molecule. This results in a weak bond between the atoms due to charge that is still strong enough to support small amounts of weight (like another drop of water or a water skipper bug)

I used to see this as a molecular biologist when mixing cell culturing fluids in the low pressure environment caused by the air flow through a biosafety cabinet. I have always assumed the phenomenon had to do with resistance to equalizing salinity and gas concentrations between the drops influencing fusion between the surfaces. The theory of air between the surfaces makes sense too for explaining my observations. In my experience, this happens more readily with fluids moved from a relatively high gas pressure environment and added to a liquid that has been in a low pressure environment for enough time to equalize. This may result in outgassing during the first few seconds after "mixing", which would result in more gas available for this barrier.

Very nice video, thanks! A long time ago I did an experiment with alcohol of the blue variant, called Spiritus in NL. !!!! WARNING BELLS !!!! FIRE & EXPLOSION HAZARD !!!! I had noticed by accident this floating drop effect in alcohol and it was much more pronounced than in water. So I decided to design an experiment. This was in the controlled space of a physics lab BTW. I fitted a large glass bowl on a metal rod clamped to a firm base. This way the rim of the bowl was perfectly free to resonate vigorously when stroked with a violin bow. Various resonating frequencies could be obtained. Then I filled the bowl with alcohol to 15mm below the rim. When the rim was agitated with the bow, droplets spouted forcefully from the glass and landed on the alcohol surface, grouping where the surface was at rest. I had made a fluid Chladni plate. The droplets contrasted white against the blue background, very beautiful. The basic pattern was a four pointed star, next up was a six pointed star. Later on I devised a way of sustained resonance via a voice coil driven by a wave generator, which allowed for even more patterns. All of this was before any digital stuff and I lost the pictures I made :-(

I think the effect should be explained by Van der Waals forces and potential energy function of two molecules. In simpe terms, if you take two melecul from the surface of the bubble and molecule on the surface of water pool and you are bringing them closely together: when they are far away, interation is 0; when they come closer, they repel each other up until the point when the potential barrier on the surface is passed and they become atract each other like molecule in the liquide do (if molecules in the liquide are away from each other they will attarch each other, but if they are too close to each other they become repel each other so there is a point of equilibrium).

As someone who works with music and general sound waves, I think I might know why cello makes those bubbles split off and bounce around when in zero gravity. Stringed instruments usually produce frequencies very similar in shape to sine waves when unfiltered. With instruments where you use a plectrum or pizzicato plucking such as classical guitar or banjo, these sine waves start and stop very suddenly and have a very acute attack. For cello, it still produces a sine wave sound, but since it is played with a bow, the attack is much less sharp. The slower introduction of the wave causes the water to slowly start to vibrate and bubble. His oscillator was playing harsh sine and square waves and causing the surface to vibrate right away. Thus, he didnt get the same effect. My best guess is that the slow attack of the wave accommodates the lack of coalescence, sort of pinching the droplet off as the waves become more severe. Of course, that's just an educated guess. I'd love to see it actually experimented upon.

There is another even more interesting effect with water that I haven't found an explanation of anywhere. The effect can be achieved by limiting the water coming out of a tap so that only a fine thin line of water comes out and before it hits the bottom of the sink it disperses into drops (so the water mustn't be a constant stream when hitting the bottom).

Now this is where things get interesting, if you take the side of a knife and hold it underneath the stream and lower or raise the knife under the stream you'll notice that depending on where you hold it the stream will be either a thin uniform line (without droplets) but if you then lower it gently you'll notice that suddenly standing droplets seem to form at the bottom of the stream. What's interesting is that it seems like information is traveling upwards the stream because by moving the knife up or down it instantaneously affects the smoothness of the entire water stream.

I think the walking water mystery can be explained in terms of water surface tension, Van der Waals Bond, and the dipole-dipole interaction between water molecules.  There is also Van der Waals equation to calculate either the force or the energy of bonding between electrically neutral molecules.I believe when the water surface is vibrating, it tends to prevent the dipole-dipole interaction or Van der Waals bonding to take its effect between two separate water surfaces or between the water droplet and the vibrating  water on the ground.  So in this particular case, the water surface tension holding the water droplet in shape will be the dominating factor.  If the water droplet is given enough or ample time to stay in contact with other water surface, then the water droplet will merge or fuse with other water as explained by Van der Waals bonding principle.

So explain this to me: when the drop first hits the flat surface with no sound waves, it hits really hard, and the surface is flat without a "catcher's mitt" (wave trough in the surface), and yet it does not coalesce! It doesn't coalesce until it has bounced several times - subsequent bounces much less hard than the first one. It seems there is something about bouncing hard that prevents coalescence! So then when you add the sound waves, all it does is make the drop continue to bounce hard instead of settle down! That's why I am not 100% convinced of the "catcher's mitt" explanation - if that's the true explanation then why does the drop without the sound wave not coalesce immediately, when the surface is flat without a "catcher's mitt" wave beneath the drop?

I certainly believe that if the drop hits the wave peak, of course it is pierced and coalesces, so by process of elimination, landing in the wave trough is necessary for it to continue bouncing. But I'm unconvinced that the "catcher's mitt" explanation is the whole reason the bouncing drop continues to bounce. I think it has more to do with the fact that the sound waves make it continue to hit the surface hard enough instead of settling, and hitting hard enough prevents coalescence for some reason (perhaps if it goes fast enough it compresses the air underneath it to get a better air cushion).

I have a different explanation for this phenomenon. The spherical surface tension of a droplet is more stable and stronger than the planar surface tension at the point of contact with the surface of water. Therefore, it takes a while until the combinational forces of gravity and force of cohesion to take over the spherical surface tensive force of the droplet. When this happens, the spherical surface tension can no longer maintain the droplet as a sphere and it coalesce with the water body.

So....the reason is the Elementary science experiment about resonance.

The cello's waveform is basically a filtered sawtooth wave (string-bow interaction makes a sawtooth wave, the instrument's body filters that wave). So it has a very sharp step at every period of the fundamental frequency. I think that sharp step is quickly adding a lot of energy to the water, giving the water inside wave crests an impulse that is strong enough to cause the crest to separate from the main water body. It works better at particular frequencies, probably because at the water blob's resonant frequencies the crests collect more sound energy into themselves (at other frequencies the energy is diffused more evenly along the surface).
Easy: Water molecules have a + and a - side, just like magnets. But on the water surface, all ends are organized so the surface get electrically charged. So all water surfaces reject eatch other.

Because you did mention the cello being I had to point out a few things.
1) The amplitude/energy and the harmonic frequencies of the played note.
2) Natural resonance of the speaker cone

the water droplets... that was the leidenfrost effect  (definition)  -  The Leidenfrost effect is a physical phenomenon in which a liquid, in near contact with a mass significantly hotter than the liquid's boiling point, produces an insulating vapor layer keeping that liquid from boiling rapidly. Due to this ‘repulsive force’, a droplet hovers over the surface rather than making physical contact with it. This is most commonly seen when cooking: one sprinkles drops of water in a pan to gauge its temperature: if the pan's temperature is at or above the Leidenfrost point, the water skitters across the pan and takes longer to evaporate than in a pan below the temperature of the Leidenfrost point (but still above boiling temperature). The effect is also responsible for the ability of liquid nitrogen to skitter across floors. It has also been used in some potentially dangerous demonstrations, such as dipping a wet finger in molten lead[1] or blowing out a mouthful of liquid nitrogen, both enacted without injury to the demonstrator.[2] The latter is potentially lethal, particularly should one accidentally swallow the liquid nitrogen. and also there is an inverse leidenfrost effect

This phenomenon is related to an aspect of space travel, actually. The finding here is that a water drop does not merge with a larger water body, because a layer of air is briefly trapped between them. A similar thing happens with metal surfaces.

Here on Earth, if you place one flat metal plate on another, of the same metal, you can then separate them easily. However, I have read in a science book that in the vacuum of space, two such metal plates would actually fuse together, because there would be no thin layer of air between them, that you would get on Earth. This is a significant issue in space craft design, obviously.

If my perfect pitch is of any use - it's noticing that the air bubble becomes distorted when the cello plays an F#2, F#3 and C#3 (or close-proximity surrounding frequencies), but not really at all when the cello plays an F#4 (noticeable at the end).
With a somewhat amateur level of acoustic physics education, I understand it's something related to resonant frequencies (and harmonic series, given the octave -> fifth pattern) but if anyone could explain exactly what is going on here, that'd be great!

It's sawtooth waves. Cello's among other bowed string instruments create rather perfect sawtooth waves, which in turn are then waveshaped into something slightly softer by constructive and destructive resonance from the often hollowed out instrument body. I presume the droplets on the inside of the space water sphere are separated from it's larger parent water body by the instant waveform reset. Now I'm wondering if the whoile air bubble would collapse inward if the sawtooth slope was the other way around, as these come in two forms, rising and falling edge sawtooth waves.

Hi SmarterEveryDay, this is amazing! I did my dissertation on water repellency on breathable fabrics! There are two main conditions to render a surface hydrophobic, it is due to surface energy and surface roughness. I guess when the speaker was vibrating, it created the perfect surface roughness where pockets of air could be trapped underneath the droplet, therefore prolonging the effect of it beading up and 'dancing' around the surface of the water. This is the same reason why some geckos can repel water! Because they have the right surface roughness for water to be repelled.

Hi Destin, let me give you a clue about why the cello makes this inside bubbles: the evolution (or devellopement) of the violin (and the cello) stopped when the the luthiers discovered the "f-hole" (seach "f-hole" on Google Images). The f-hole is the shape of the air holes on top of the violin (its cello cousin did get the same holes) that are supposed the "let out" all the frequencies from the inside of the instrument. Before this "last generation" violins (as they are today) these holes had many different shapes (circles, half circles, laces), but none of them did sound right. What made the f-hole the perfect (and final) shape was that it is the surface of a sphere. Peel an orange or a tangerine the right way and you get the f-hole shape (search "peel tangerine f-hole" on Youtube). And BECAUSE it's the surface of a sphere it can "let out" all the frequencies of the music's spectrum. Now you can easily imagine why the sound, that is shaped as a sphere by the f-holes of the cello, does indeed turn into spheres. But that's just a clue.

I submit that the "air layer" theory is unlikely. It seems to me that the phenomena is more related to differences in droplet and pool surface tensions, internal droplet pressures, surface pressures and deformations than it does any "air layer".

If the internal pressure according to F = Gamma * L and F = P*A of a water droplet is less than the pressure of the pool surface of 1 ATM pushing up, and upon impact, the difference in surface tensions and deformation of the droplet and the surface absorb the impact energy to maintain said internal droplet pressure and tension of the pool's surface. Intuitively it seems to me that the surface tension of the droplet is greater than the tension of the surface causing the droplet to "bounce" all the while the droplet is able to deform much more than the pool's surface and absorbs said impact. On impact wouldn't the molecules be squeezed together i.e., density increased? Once the droplet bounces and comes to rest, the residence time might be the time for all forces on the water molecules of the droplet/pool interface to reach equilibrium and assume new molecular attractions, thus coalescing into the pool's surface.

If the "air layer" is true, then wouldn't it stand to reason that a much larger droplet, imply that an increase surface area would trap more air and be resident longer? Should it bounce less? More? What would happen if we increased the impact energy? Would it even bounce? I believe that the experiment where the residence time diminished with decreasing external pressure is affecting the droplet's and pool's internal pressures. It is clear that the droplet bounces quite readily and multiple times retaining its surface independent of the pool's surface before coming to rest without coalescing...something is keeping the droplet together, yes? I believe that the oscillating pool surface experiment is where the pool's perturbations constantly push against the droplet's surface moving it on a constantly changing pool surface (as well as absorbing it in the troughs as stated in the video). I.e., the pool never lets it rest in one place long enough for the droplet to completely equilibrate molecularly and coalesce. How does the air layer theory work in this experiment? But, then again I'm simply speculating.

It's funny and sad that a "NASA scientist" wouldn't understand something that for me was part of these science books aimed at schoolkids. Whats happening is the water drops on their way down become electrically charged. The same process that creates thunderstorms in the clouds. The water molecule dipoles in the drop all turn to face outward so to say and form an electromagnetic skin. While the puddle or bathtub is connected to ground and has only the normal water surface. Observe how the real phenomenon with longtime 'droplet dancing' always takes place in a certain humid athmosphere and after a longer fall gave time to charge/magnetize the droplet. There is no air cushion involved as you claim.

Could it be that the internal kinetics of the drop prevent it from homogenizing with the still water below?
Just like the drops hitting the vibrating surface, it could be that the spin and internal vibrations in the drops caused by the drop forming and rolling off the beveled needle point and the air resistance as it fell are stopping the surfaces from merging.

Eliminating or enhancing these variables could be a great way to prove or disprove the current air layer theory.

- Cut the beveled needle point straight to prevent spin or run water down a glass stir rod.
- Try imparting vibrations in the drops via a speaker on a syringe
- Try imparting more spin on the drops (air current or a pin head at the edge of the falling drips path)

Maybe the decreased air pressure in the study you mentioned caused a stiller drop and reduced surface tension.

Lots of maybes but something to think about.

Hey Destin

I'm finishing up my second year of studying mechanical engineering (in South Africa) and I'm telling you it's not always easy.

Sometimes I wonder if it's worth the effort to carry on... and then YOU come and post a video like THIS and I literally start crying when I see a water droplet dancing to cello music in space. You said you want us to think it's beautiful... And well, I absolutely do. And then I realise this is exactly the kind of stuff I want to do some day.

I actually noticed this effect quite a few times, especially a few nights back when I was taking out my contact lenses, tired after studying, but instead of sleeping I immediately started playing around with the release height of the drop to see what effect the greater impulse will have on the frequency of drops that fail to coalesce.

I guess what I'm trying to say is, thank you for making me realise that I TRUELY want to be an engineer (and that I already am one at heart).

Kind regards

I think the reason it forms the air pocket even when it bounces is the same reason why when you throw an object from a high distance into a body of water causing it to react as a solid rather than a fluid.  Despite the water being the same substance or because we cannot remove temperature variation in the droplet it behaves as seen with a hot pan and water it allows the water to act as two independent substances due to them both repelling another from their surface tension as the water hits it either punches threw due to sheer weight or the weight of the water is small enough that it's able to impact and not break the surface tension of the water forming the air pocket for prolong periods of time more than one bounce. So it's all about the viscosity of water a level that varies on temperature and the droplets even at a small distance may change as a standing body of water will hold a different temperature then a smaller body quickly influenced by outside air temperature causing it to warm or cool faster this difference in temperature can create a change in the viscosity. In space it seems it's just droplets being pulled off the water that respond the same way they would as outlined above even without gravity the tension remains constant and could probably be tested by smacking someone with a water balloon in "zero G (there is still gravity in space but it's affected by orbital space to counteract the downward force pulling it back to the earth)" despite it having no gravity it still carries weight and so as a bullet can cause impact thus creating a force equal to it's mass though lessened it still exist.

It was my understanding that a water generally has a slightly electronegative surface (though at the moment I couldn't find anything to verify this claim). However, it could explain the general behavior seen. With extended periods of two water surfaces touching causing a shift in the molecules along the surface allowing gravity to overcome the repulsive force along the surface. More brief interactions will not give the time needed to force a shift in the molecule alignment and the two surfaces will remain distinct.

A couple of things that could help test this is varying the surface tension by either temperature or impurities in the water.

Mercury could also be observed for similar effects but I'm not sure how much the much higher density would play a factor even with the greater surface tension, but being a non-polar liquid it shouldn't show any beading on the surface if it is caused by what I suggested above.

Often when refilling the lens case with new contact lens solution, if I shot the solution into the case with just the right pressure on the bottle and the right angle into the case, the whole case would fill with these drops and they would swirl around in the case and then finally coalesce.  I tried it recently after +Physics Girl did the video on "antibubbles" but I wasn't very successful.  But back when I discovered the effect I was using a different brand of contact lens solution, and maybe that brand had some ingredient, not present in the brand I now use, that promoted the effect. My guess as to 'why does the cello shake loose water droplets?' is based on two things: how a bowed string instrument produces sound, and the pitch of a cello.

A bowed string makes sound by the bow 'catching' the string then losing grip, over and over. This produces a wave very similar to a sawtooth wave, which kinda looks like NNNNN (best I can do with text). This type of wave is like lots of tiny impacts that are so close together their sound waves coalesce into a single continuous sound. I think this 'multiple-impact' style wave helps to shake loose some of the peak resonances of the water.

Secondly, the cello can produce lower pitches than other stringed instruments, and lower frequencies can sympathetically resonate through solid objects better than higher frequencies. You'll notice on the space video the lowest notes on the cello are the ones that are able to shake loose droplets, whereas the higher notes do very little. This is simply the cello finding sympathetic resonance with the surface tension on the inner bubble.

What is interesting is the video appears to show that really low pitches resonate with the outer water surface, and slightly higher low pitches resonate with the inner water surface. I'm guessing the size of the surface changes what pitches are able to form standing waves, which is similar to how sound works in air, where the distance between surfaces dictates what frequencies will 'stand'.

The droplets breaking off the inner bubble because of the cello music got me so intrigued I spent almost 2 hours scouring the web in an effort to if not explain, at least find a plausible explanation for the phenomenon. Going under the assumption "I bet there's some water-cello resonance thing going on". This led me to:

* look up the resonant frequency of water (very conflicting answers, not sure what to make of any of it)
* look up the characteristic frequencies of cellos (success)
* look up the sheet music for Bach's cello suite No. 1 (success)
* try to quickly teach myself how to read said sheet music (success)
* look up the frequencies for the notes I'd found (success)
* not trusting my brand new sheet music reading skills, I downloaded and installed Audacity and ran a spectrum analysis on the music (turns out I was pretty much spot on, hurray)
* take a detour trying to figure out if it's purely sound pressure related (got stuck on the fact that surface tension is expressed in N/m and sound pressure in N/m^2, which is so tantalizingly close yet so far; again not sure what to make of that)
* give up my attempt to find a quick and dirty answer
* realize my attempt was probably naive to begin with, since there's probably all sorts of refraction and reflection effects going on within the water itself, the air bubble trapped inside and on the boundary between the two

So I guess I got smarter today, not least of which was "don't overthink things at o dark thirty at night".

So i guess the flat surface of the water gives enough surface tension to cause the droplet's membrane to fail and therefore separate and absorb

When vibrating the membrane is never forced apart as its treated like a "hot potato"

It works the same way in that your hand wont be burned if you toss a hot potato between two hands, as the heat (tension on the membrane) dissipates (reforms to a sphere) as it is pushed airborne and softly caught again by the vibrating water and the cycle repeats.

The droplet's membrane will always have a chance to fail if it hits somewhere without all factors working together, much like the water balloon comparison as if you started to catch where you would normally end a catch it wouldn't take advantage of being decelerated and would take the full force of the catch/fall.

If you weren't actively timing the catch then there is always a chance of that happening, and the vibrating water is not timing its catches, but it is consistent so it usually stays a droplet for a while.
